Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Linking Changing Uses of Property with Urban Transformations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
During periods of social and economic stress, how do organizations collaborate to rework rules and norms of property law so that unused land can be activated as a common resource? And why, even when conditions might seem ripe, do some such collaborations not bear fruit?
This project contributes to ongoing interdisciplinary research on urban resilience, and sheds new light on how people bring about and govern common resources in urban settings. It does so by investigating how people and organizations in one of America?s largest cities have periodically organized, and dissolved, regimes for governing land as a common resource. Long term agreements concerning use deploy urban resources flexibly to allow communities to address changing priorities. Governance of common resources has long been a focus of concern across the social sciences; little scholarship on urban resilience and property regimes is theoretically informed by historical evidence. The project combines archival and ethnographic methods to explore connections between urban farming and property law in Chicago, between the 1890s and today. The ethnographic component includes collaborative research with policy organizations. The final part develops two contemporary case studies as points of comparison.

By learning from past episodes of urban resilience and ongoing land-use experimentation, the project aims to inform future urban policy and planning. It will ultimately propose, through a policy report possible institutional designs for governing urban land as a common productive resource. The report will be useful for cities as they consider land redevelopment to address changing needs. In addition, the project will train students in the social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How and why do people make land available for urban agriculture, particularly in response to social and economic crises? What has prevented this form of land use from becoming a more permanent feature of the urban landscape? This project explored these questions through a comparative-historical and ethnographic case study of Chicago, during three periods between the 1890s and 2015. It found that social reformers from community-based organizations, city agencies, and private companies have repeatedly collaborated to make vacant land available for residents to use for gardens and farms. Before World War One and during the Great Depression, this served as a means of providing welfare support to the poor and unemployed. This form of welfare provision remains relevant to urban policy. Since the 1990s, reformers have become increasingly interested in how urban agriculture can address unemployment, poverty, and other social problems by creating productive uses for vacant land, particularly in neighborhoods devastated by deindustrialization and depopulation. 

The project explains how urban agriculture has served as a form of use-based welfare. Rather than providing income supports, social services, or assets, use-based welfare provides the right to use and benefit from, but not own, a resource. In this case, that resource is vacant land. Rather than achieving redistribution by taxing property and transferring its value, use-based welfare transfers by reallocating use rights, through adjustments to the rules, norms, and forms of property. For example, social reformers before World War One worked to develop a social norm that would require property owners to share their unused land with the poor, who could put it to use. And during the Depression, companies and local governments experimented with requiring laid-off workers to grow gardens before they could access other forms of unemployment support. When reformers tried to make such experiments a permanent part of the city’s landscape, they encountered resistance from landowners and business interests. Today, people are working to make land access for urban agriculture secure, affordable, and responsive to neighborhood priorities by adapting models developed by open space land trusts and community land trusts. The use of land trusts to permanently protect urban land for farms and gardens has garnered support from both funders and city officials.

This project contributes to an interdisciplinary, socio-legal understanding of how land use and welfare provision are interrelated. It provides a critical perspective on recent scholarship concerning the urban commons, which has frequently taken community gardens and urban farms as paradigmatic examples of commons governance in the city. At the time of this report, an article based on this research was forthcoming in the Fordham Urban Law Journal, and additional manuscripts were being prepared for submission to sociology journals and law reviews.

The project has also contributed to discussions concerning urban land use policy in Chicago and beyond. The project’s ethnographic component included participatory research with Chicago-based food policy organizations. This led to recommendations for how urban agriculture could be incorporated as a land use in the Millennium Reserve, a region in south Chicago designated by the State of Illinois for environmental and economic renewal. At the time of this report, a chapter on land tenure models for urban farming was forthcoming in Community and Regional Food Systems: Identifying Innovations and Promoting Successes, a volume edited by Steven Ventura and Martin Bailkey, to be published by the University of Iowa Press.
